label: Letter from Fong Lee Wong to Laura M. Bragg, September 16, 1929
description: In this three page handwritten letter, Fong Lee Wong expresses his sorrow that Laura M. Bragg had been ill. He writes none of the expected Chinese students are going to attend The Citadel. He met his female friend in Chicago, IL. He learns Chia Mei may be in aviator school and he expects to return on the twenty-first, signing his letter, "Little Captain."

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: In this three page handwritten letter, Fong Lee Wong expresses his sorrow that Laura M. Bragg had been ill. He writes none of the expected Chinese students are going to attend The Citadel. He met his female friend in Chicago, IL. He learns Chia Mei may be in aviator school and he expects to return on the twenty-first, signing his letter, "Little Captain."

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information contact The Citadel Archives and Museum at Daniel Library, The Citadel, 171 Moultrie Street, Charleston, SC 29409

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 dpi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Washington, D.C.
Sept. 16, 1929

My dear Miss Bragg:

	About three weeks ago, I had the pleasure of receiving your letter when I was in Columbus, Ohio. I was very sorry to learn that you had been sick and at the same time I could not help feeling greatly thankful that you first wrote to me after your sickness. Had I not busily engaged in translating a small English military book into Chinese and waited for the coming of new Chinese students so that I would be to tell you when I would be home with new students, as you had asked me, I would have answered long ago. For this reason I hope you would excuse me for my delay.

	Now regarding the new students, I am very sorry to say that none of them will come to the Citadel, but all have [2] changed their mind and gone to other schools. So I will come home with myself.

	I met my friend at Chicago on the fourteenth. Mr. Li was also there and insisted in detaining her one day in order to have a rest. But one day in Chicago made her more ]. feel tired in--stead of refreshed [sic]. And as she had to get everything arranged as early as possible in Washington and as the re-opening of the Citadel drew near, so she and I left Chicago yesterday by 12:30 train and arrived here in Washington at 8:05 in the morning. She is still in a tired condition and I am not quite different. But I can not delay and I do ot like to delay any longer to write to you. So inspite [sic] of the poor work of my brain, I am writing to you, hoping you will forgive me for my poor and illegible hand writing 

	[3] One of my boy friends, who came this summer, had bought Chinese cups and the four books of English translation. But he had broken the cups when he reached Tokio [alternative spelling for Tokyo], Japan on his voyage to the United States. So I am very sorry that I shall be able to present to you only the four--books. My friend has brought a light shade for you and I will bring it home.

	When I wrote my last two letters I thought Chia--Mei had already gone to Taxas [sic Texas]. This was also what Mrs. House thought as I found from her letter to me. Now I think he must be in the aviation school, Taxas[sic].

	I will be home on the twenty-first, but at what time I am now unable to tell you. I am feeling very glad as I shall see you pretty soon.

	Affectionately yours
	
	Little Captain

[From:]F.L. Wong
c/o Chinese Educational Mission
2645 Connecticut Ave.
Washington, D.C.

[Addressed:] Miss Laura M. Bragg
38 Chalmers Street
Charleston, S.C.
